page.title: 04LOCAL HISTORY 3
page.content: It is interesting to note that the settlement was documented by the Normans in its Saxon form in non-other than the 'Domesday Book'. {(Local {history)} During William 'Rufus' reign (1087 - 1100), the area became known as the Lordship of Hope, owned primarily by the Stewards of Chester. Edward I is famous for his conquest of Wales and Caergwrle was involved in this. His war with the Welsh and the involvement of Dafydd, brother of Llywelyn, Prince of Wales, prompted the construction of two fine stone castles. The first one was constructed by Dafydd with Edward's grant of 100 marks in 1277, but was slighted by its founder in retaliation after a disagreement with the King, who built the second in 1282. Dafydd fled into the hills, but was captured and executed.
